subject: Re: [junit] Reporting historical test results
msgSnippet: Hi All, Just a quick note to let you know that Clover 2.0 will include this functionality. To be specific, Clover 2.0 will allow you to build up a historical
messageBody:
Hi All,

Just a quick note to let you know that Clover 2.0 will include this
functionality. To be specific, Clover 2.0 will allow you to build up a
historical record of JUnit test results and report on them, in much the
same way Clover 1.x does with historical coverage and metrics information.

Clover 2.0 is scheduled for beta release in Q2 2005.

Regards,
-Brendan
http://www.cenqua.com
Software Tools for Continuous Quality


Morten Grum wrote:
> Hi all
>
> We miss exactly this sort of history presentation of results giving a quick
> view at new tests, removed tests, new passes/failings and a focus on failing
> tests.
>
> How best to proceed I don't know. We've been thinking of using XSLT on the
> TESTS-TestSuites.xml files which our nighly build today saves in date
> stamped report folders. But we're fairly new to XSLT and slow at getting it
> right.
>
> We'd like to support the best we can to get something smart here.
>
> Morten
>
>
>
>>-----Original Message-----
>>From: didoss@... [mailto:didoss@...]
>>Sent: 13 January 2005 15:53
>>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>>Subject: RE: [junit] Reporting historical test results
>>
>>
>>Not hearing anyone running forward with a solution, I'm left with two
>>questions: one for the group, and one for some 'higher up'.
>>
>>For the group: do you think that this would be useful functionality for
>>someone to try and creat?
>>
>>For some 'higher up': if I were interested in writing this code, what is
>>the process for that?
>>
>>thanks, Dianne
>>
>>-------------- Original message --------------
>>
>>Paul Dominic writes:
>>
>> If you are generating JUnit Report through Ant,
>>definitely you
>> should write one build.xml file. Before generating new report,
>>why not you
>> take copy of the previous report. In Ant API contains copy tag
>>and move
>> tag. So
>> first step you take a back up using Copy/ Move tag.
>> Second step you clear your old report using delete tag.
>> Third step create report folder again.
>> Finally you generate new report.
>>
>>Are you saying there's no extension for JUnit that sends the test
>>results/report into a database, using JDBC or some other mechanism? I'm
>>new to JUnit, too, but I find it hard to believe that there isn't
>>already software to store historical test results in a database.
>>
>>
>>Todd.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
